div1.p: Funeral Services for Dr. H.R. Carter Will Be Tomorrow

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, September 15, 1925
div1.opener:
3 N S Health Service
K
Post
Washington, D. C.
SEP 15 1925
div1.p:
FUNERAL SERVICES
FOR DR. H. R. CARTER
WILL BE TOMORROW

SURGEON GENERAL'S AID
HAD NOTABLE CAREER

Nominated for Nobel Prize
for Work in Eradicating
Yellow Fever.

Funeral services will be held at
10 o'clock tomorrow morning for
Dr. Henry R. Carter, assistant sur-
geon general, who died yesterday
morning at the Westmoreland
apartments after a prolonged ill-
ness.

Services will be held first at his
apartment and then at St. Mar-
garet's church. Archdeacon Ster-
ling Claiborne, of Sewanee, Tenn.,
and the Rev. Herbert Scott Smith,
of St. Margaret's will officiate. The
body will be taken at noon to Ash-
land, Va., for interment.

Dr. Carter, long identified with
Dr. Walter Reed and Maj. Gen.
Gorgas in fighting yellow fever, was
a native of Virginia and 73 years
old. He entered what is now the
public health service in 1879, serv-
ing as chief quarantine officer for
Cuba and in the same capacity for
the Isthmian canal commission, sub-
sequently becoming director of hos-
pitals for the latter. Variously he
served as sanitary supervisor to the
Peruvian government and as a
member of the yellow fever council
of the international health board of
the Rockefeller foundation.

Outstanding in his notable career
was the determination of the pe-
riod of extrinsic incubation of yel-
low fever, a foundation on which
Dr. Reed and his commission work-
ed and for which Dr. Carter was
nominated for the Nobel prize.

Dr. Carter was the founder of
the present maritime quarantine
system and enunciated the prin-
ciples relating to the bearing of the
impounding of great bodies of
water on the production of malaria
and inaugurated control measures
for malaria in the army canton-
ments during the world war.

Dr. Carter served through many
yellow fever epidemics in the South,
notably that at MacHenry, Miss.,
several years ago. He contributed
freely to medical journals.

He is survived by two sons, Dr.
Henry R. Carter, jr., of Birming-
ham, Ala.; and Edward Champ
Carter, of Baltimore; a brother,
Charles Harrison Carter, of Port-
land, Oreg., two sisters, Mrs. Nancy
Carter Redd, of Ashland, Va., and
Miss Mary C. Carter, of North
River Plantation, Va., and a daugh-
ter, Miss Laura Carter.
